habitat_description:
The Snowy Plover (Charadrius alexandrines) is a small plover that can be found along the Gulf and Pacific Coasts year-round as well as at interior sites in the West during summer.  Six subspecies of Snowy Plover exist, but only two occur in the U.S.: the Western Snowy Plover (C. a. nivosus) and the Southeastern Snowy Plover (C. a. tenuirostris).  This account and associated model encompasses both of these subspecies.  Another USGAP model exists for the Western Snowy Plover which includes both interior and coastal breeding populations.

Western Snowy Plovers breed along the Pacific Coast and at interior sites in the West and winter along the Gulf and Pacific Coasts.  The Pacific Coast breeding population of the Western Snowy Plover refers to individuals nesting within 50 mi of the Pacific Ocean, is distinct from interior breeding Western Snowy Plovers, and is listed as threatened under the Endangered Species Act of 1973 (USFWS 2007).

In Arizona, breeding is limited to only two locales in the Willcox Playa in Coschise County and Painted Rock Reservoir in Maricopa County (AZGF 2002).  In New Mexico, the Snowy Plover is a summer resident along the barren alkali bordered lakes of the Rio Grande, Estancia, and Pecos Valleys (Ligon 1961).  Breeding in New Mexico occurs primarily at Bitter Lake Refuge and at the Bosque Del Apache NWR (Ligon 1961).  Breeding and summering habitats in Colorado, Nevada, and Utah occur along beaches, dry mud or salt flats, and sandy shores of rivers, lakes, and ponds (Andrews and Righter 1992, NatureServe). 

Pacific Coast Western Snowy Plovers breed above the high tide line on beaches along coasts, creeks, and rivermouths; sand spits; sparsely-vegetated dunes; and salt pans at lagoons and estuaries.  Bluff-backed beaches, dredged material disposal sites, salt pond levees, dry salt ponds, and river bars are also used, but less frequently (USFWS 2007). Nests are usually placed in areas where driftwood and vegetation are sparse, but are often placed next to or under small objects (e.g., shells, wood, small plants, etc.; Page et al. 2009).  Nests can be up to 7 miles from the ocean beach (Page et al. 2009), and up to 150 m from water (Kingery 1998).  Winter habitat is the same as summer but also includes man-made salt ponds and estuarine sand and mud flats.  They feed on invertebrates found in wet or dry sand, kelp laying on beaches, salt pans, dredge-spoil sites, edges of marshes, salt pond edges, and the edges of lagoons.  

Interior breeding Western Snowy Plovers occur at scattered locations in the West up to 3,048 m in elevation.  They nest on riverine sand bars; barren shores of inland saline, alkaline lakes, ponds, and reservoirs; and salt evaporation ponds (Page et al. 2009).  Breeding has not been documented on the salt flats devoid of water, but nesting can occur where a distant small seep is the only apparent surface water (Page et al. 2007).  

The Southeastern Snowy Plover nests in isolated locations along the Gulf Coast on sandy beaches and, in at least one case, on a little-used parking lot (Eglin Air Force Base; Page et al. 2007).  It feeds along beaches and tide flats; gathering food from the surface of the beach (Page et al. 2007).  

Non-breeding habitats for all Snowy Plover subspecies generally occur on coastal areas, such as beaches, flats, lagoons, and salt-evaporated ponds; but also in inland wastewater ponds and saline lakes (NatureServe 2012). 

N. Tarr, 25April2012.
